Award.AwardTitle: Support Student and Early Career Attendance at the Inaugural Triennial Earth Space Summit
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports participation of students and early-career scientists at the Triennial Earth-Sun Summit (TESS), a joint meeting of the Space Physics and Aeronomy Section of the American Geophysical Union and the Solar Physics Division of the American Astronomical Society. TESS is intended to be a gathering of the entire Heliophysics community, including distinct sub-disciplines devoted to studies of the Sun, the near-Earth space environment, and their interactions with the Earth's atmosphere. The goal of this conference is to promote greater interaction and unity within this community. This increasingly interdisciplinary effort is necessary to understand, predict, and mitigate the effects of "space weather".

This program will be administered by the American Astronomical Society (AAS), the principal professional organization for US astronomers. They have very successfully and economically administered similar programs in the past, and the proposed procedures ensure that these funds will provide the maximum benefit to the astronomical and geospace communities at minimal administrative cost.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The outcome of this grant was direct support to early-career scientists to attend relevant and important scientific conferences relevant to heliophysics, the detailed study of how the Sun functions and its impact on the Earth and the Solar System.  Support was provided to attend the Tri-ennial Earth-Sun Summit (TESS) and the Solar Physics Division conference.  Results from the TESS meeting were summarized in an earlier Annual Report.

A total of 13 graduate students and 5 early career researchers were selected for support from the TESS grant to participate in the 2016 AAS Solar Physics Division (SPD) stand alone meeting, hosted by National Solar Observatory on the campus of the University of Colorado in Boulder on 31 May to 03 June.
The 2016 SPD conference, which brought together scientists and students from around the world for presentations and discussions on cutting edge solar astronomy, had 328 registered participants. Of these, 32% were students and early career researchers (85 graduate students, 6 undergraduates, 13 early career researchers).


The awarded graduate students received a regular registration fee waiver of $280, while early career researcher received a $460 regular registration fee waiver. The total amount of financial support provided from the TESS grant was $5,940. Selection of the students and early career researchers were made by the SPD Scientific Organizing Committee, in coordination with the Local Organizing Committee.
